docs.title: Python
docs.text:
You can install the Python bindings using pip (after building):

pip install .

docs.title: R
docs.text:
You can install the R package using devtools (after building):

# In R
install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install("path/to/grid-fit")

docs.title: Python
docs.text:
import gridfit
# Interpolate between 0 and 1 with 1 interval
result = gridfit.interp(0, 1, 1)
print(result)  # [0.5]

docs.title: R
docs.text:
library(gridfit)
# Interpolate between 0 and 1 with 1 interval
result <- interp(0, 1, 1)
print(result)  # [0.5]

For more details, see the README or source code.

docs.title: Bindings: How C++ Compiling Works for Python and R
Overview Diagram
docs.text:
flowchart TD
    A[C++ Source Code] -->|Compile with CMake/pybind11| B(Python Shared Library .so)
    A -->|Compile with CMake/Rcpp| C(R Shared Library .so)
    B -->|Install with pip| D[Python Package]
    C -->|Install with devtools| E[R Package]
    D -->|import gridfit| F[Python User]
    E -->|library(gridfit)| G[R User]

docs.title: C++ Core Development
docs.text: You write and edit your C++ code (e.g., in src/).

docs.title: Compiling for Bindings
docs.text:
• To use your C++ code in Python or R, you must compile it into a shared library (e.g., .so on Linux, .dll on Windows, .dylib on macOS).
  • This is usually done with CMake or a similar build system, which creates the shared library and the necessary binding code (using pybind11 for Python, Rcpp for R).

docs.title: Python Package
docs.text:
• The Python package (created with pybind11) includes the compiled shared library (e.g., gridfit.cpython-310-x86_64-linux-gnu.so).
  • When you install the Python package (e.g., with pip install .), the build process compiles the C++ code and places the shared library in the package directory.
  • Python imports this shared library as a module.

docs.title: R Package
docs.text:
• The R package (created with Rcpp) also includes the compiled shared library (e.g., gridfit.so).
  • When you build/install the R package (e.g., with devtools::install()), R compiles the C++ code and places the shared library in the package’s libs/ directory.
  • R loads this shared library when you load the package.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
• The C++ code is compiled into a shared library for both Python and R.
  • The packages (Python and R) include the compiled version, not the raw C++ source (except for development or source distributions).
  • You need to recompile whenever you change the C++ code and want those changes available in Python or R.

docs.title: Development Guide
docs.text: This page provides instructions for developers working on the grid-fit library.

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/rae-gh/grid-fit.git
cd grid-fit

docs.title: 2. Set Up Conda Environment
docs.text:
Create and activate a conda environment for development:

conda create -n gridfit-dev python=3.10 cmake make gxx_linux-64 -y
conda activate gridfit-dev

You can add more dependencies to this environment as needed (e.g., pybind11, pytest, etc.).

docs.title: 3. Install Python Library in Editable Mode
docs.text:
pip install -e .

This allows you to edit the Python code and have changes reflected immediately.

docs.title: 4. Build C++ Core and Bindings
docs.text: Follow the instructions in the README or CMakeLists.txt to build the C++ core and bindings for Python and R.

docs.title: 5. Keep R Library Consistent
docs.text: When updating the C++ core, ensure the R bindings are updated as well. Use the examples in examples/R/ to test.

docs.title: Python
docs.text:
Run the integration tests with pytest:

pytest tests/python

docs.title: R
docs.text:
Run the R integration test script:

Rscript tests/R/test_interp.R

Make sure both tests pass before pushing changes.

docs.title: Pre-commit Hooks
docs.text: This project uses pre-commit hooks to help maintain code quality for Python and C++ files. Hooks will automatically check formatting and linting before each commit.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Install pre-commit (if not already): 
    pip install pre-commit
  2. Install the hooks: 
    pre-commit install

Now, every time you commit, black and flake8 will check Python files, and clang-format will check C++ files. You can add more hooks or languages as needed.
